question: Can I sing later?
Mr. Showbiz?
How are you, daddy?

answer: Well, you know, I never sleep.
question: Are you getting much sleep?
Are you a good nappy changer?
ORGAN: Diapers?
You're a good diaper changer?
You're liking being a dad?
I mean, you can -- you can give me some advice on fatherhood, right?

answer: Yes, because I -- I was neglectful when I saw you at "America's Got Talent," because you were too busy.
question: Really?
Really?
You're a sports fan, right?

answer: Yes, no one knew who you were in America.
question: Because your running joke with me, of course, is it was being -- I'm not famous, right?
Does that sicken you?
You're threatening me with physical violence, aren't you?
Do you wake -- I'm going to ask you this -- do you wake up some mornings and just think, "Good God, I am lying next to Mariah Carey"?
-- this is permanent, this is real?

answer: I was so sure because that was Mariah Carey.
question: Why were you so sure?
Did she know that she was your dream girl?
But who's the boss at home?
I mean, that's how you get to the top, isn't it?
ORGAN: You're doing it for four hours, right?

answer: One-thirty -- and I'm probably in the studio until about 7:30.
question: You get up at 1:00 -- you're on air at 1:30?
When do you sleep?

answer: No, maybe two hours a night.
question: Do you sleep much at all?
Because it becomes very contagious, doesn't it?

answer: It's all how it's handle, in my opinion.
question: ORGAN: Do you have any credibility issues with the way that stars are found on these talent shows?
And we do see competitors coming on and trying it on, don't we?
This is like his second hundred million dollar deal, right?
When you see people becoming instantly very famous on this show, how do you feel, as somebody who's in that bubble of fame?

answer: I do -- I just hope they know what they're in store for, because I would say if you weigh it out, the things -- the good things about fame are probably smaller than the bad things about fame, especially if you don't know how to handle it, because it's a magnifying glass.
question: Do you worry about that?
Where do you draw the line, the parity, because you're both very famous?

answer: There is, but if you give them enough, if you -- if you feed the sharks, they won't attack you.
question: Is there a line that can still be drawn if you do that, do you think, in terms of personal privacy?
When you see other celebrities moaning about being famous, what do you feel about it?

answer: There really is none, but if I had to, I would say honesty plus confidence.
question: If you could simplify it for somebody, what's the secret of being a good stand-up?

answer: It's -- everything is topical to me, because a lot of it is about my life.
question: How much of your act is topical?

answer: Yes, I got to DJ his inauguration party.
question: -- you got a great honor, didn't you?
How did that feel?
How do you think he's doing?

answer: I don't -- he'd -- he'd have too many bodyguards around him.
question: ORGAN: -- would you -- would you take him out?

answer: I think there was a time where --
question: Because you've wanted to, haven't you?

answer: If you were entering the show --
question: What is my talent?
What are you saying singing?
What would you actually do -- other than stand-up comedy, what would you do if you walked on stage on "AGT"?
You want a freestyle?

answer: Well, before I got on this show, it was very boring.
question: How good are you?
Can you quite believe what's happened to you?
And I love that it's an overnight sensation, but it took me 32 years to get there, you know?

answer: Well, I was always a singer, and I had a band for about 15 years, and I was the lead singer of the band, and I would do impressions of singers.
question: What was the act?
And that was the magical tipping point, wasn't it?
Can I sing later?
Do you ever regret losing the anonymity?

answer: Of course, I'm the guy who spends all his money.
question: Tell me I'm wrong, Winston was always about the money, right?
So, do you want to perform?

answer: That's what he wants to hear.
question: Can I do the Roy Orbison?
Are you pleased with it?

answer: This is something I've worked my whole life to get to.
question: Is it the culmination of the dream for you?
And in many ways, saved the kind of life you may have had, right?

answer: Oh, yes, she's still around and she --
question: Was she around to see that?

answer: RIMM: She's having probably the best of time, more than anyone.
question: What does she make of it?

answer: Well, you know, if someone can do it in the family, I'm sure they would.
question: Amazing thing to be able to do that, isn't it?
It's called "Michael Grimm," right?

answer: I'm going to sing a song off the album.
